snippet: A clerk of the Supreme Court provided a rare inside look at how the justices are prepared to rule on matters of life and death in capital cases.
abstract: Adam Liptak Sidebar column notes that process by which the Supreme Court granted convicted murderer John Balentine a stay of execution, as described by the Court's emergency application clerk Danny Bickell, provides a rare inside look at how the justices are prepared to rule on matters of life and death in capital cases.
lead_paragraph: A clerk of the Supreme Court provided a rare inside look at how the justices are prepared to rule on matters of life and death in capital cases.

headline.print_headline: To Beat the Execution Clock, the Justices Prepare Early
headline.seo: To Beat Execution Clock, Justices Prepare Early — Sidebar
headline.main: To Beat the Execution Clock, the Justices Prepare Early
